Related to #1858

Yes this is good to have in place some time in the future.

Here are some thoughts:
- End user of homebrew should NOT need to compile the `wsk` CLI on their computer
- We should move the CLI to it's own Repository
- We should configure a jenkins server in Apache Infra or OpenWhisk server with alarm tirgger to do nightly/commit releases
  - Create git Tag/Release with something like 1.0.0-dev_$timestamp
  - Compile `wsk` and attached to github release page or add link and host binary some where
- To cut release version, we need to go thru Apache process, cut the version `1.0.0`, vote, create source zip for source release, publish binary and create tag/release github page.
- nightly are easy and schedule and always gives you latest and fresh copy
- voted release take some more effort so they will be release in cadence that allows time for the release cutting process.
- Submit formula to homebrew that relies on the binaries

Looking forward for someone to work on this in some time in the future.

A couple of thoughts on this PR:

- I agree on not retrying on /run which makes little sense after /init worked we can assume the container is healthy.
- However this PR does not yet address the root cause of prematurely exiting containers:
When an action runs and that action somehow manages to kill the container (i.e. container is stopped or dead afterwards), a subsequent pause will fail, followed by a failed unpause which currently is ignored and a call to /init follows.

@perryibm keep me honest here but I think with the change to runc for pause / unpause we can tighten the checks here again and assume the following:

1. A cold-started container is running
2. After an action has run, the container is still running
2.1. If it is not running (i.e. pause fails), the container is deemed broken and gets gc'ed
3. After pause the container is paused
4. After unpause the container is running
4.1. If it is not running (i.e. unpause fails), the container is deemed broken and gets gc'ed


So IMHO we still need another PR for fixing the invoker.

> So IMHO we still need another PR for fixing the invoker.

This is correct and understood. We can roll that additional change into this PR as well, but I'm taking this on as a sort of Invoker training exercise, so it may not be as expedient as we all might like 😉
@domdom82 there were two actions to take - this is the first of them. So yes, we need to address the second issue as well but that can be done as a separate PR.

LGTM.  Retry should be explicit and without a default as is done.  Can I have one more PG please?

We do need to address the underlying issue of state inconsistency but I agree it should be a separate PR as it's orthogonal.   The fundamental problem is potentially even more difficult because the inconsistency can arise without any operation (pause/resume) to witness the container going away so we might want to think about remedies there as well.

20 seconds / 2 seconds means 10 missing pings to be considered offline?  Given the granularity, perhaps we could make it more like 10 seconds / 1 seconds to tighten things.   Is it the case that it takes only a single ping to restore it?

I m executing the following series of actions 

wskadmin user create guest1 -ns shared
.........
wskadmin user create guest2 -ns shared
...........
 wskadmin user list shared
*************************************************   guest1

So it just listed out 1 user in namespace "shared" . Is this how this should work ? I was expecting that we have created 2 users guest1 and guest1 in namespace shared. So the wskadmin user list command should list both users.
Another doubt which i have is after running the following command, it says namespace exists .Why ?

wskadmin user create guest1 -ns shared
Namespace already exists


What i was understanding guest1/guest2 are users in namespace shared right ? Can you explain the relation ship between users and namespace and what context is used in the wsk commands ?
merged 4550ac1316d4e1690b7d5e461c26977d7abca34a
@rabbah assigning to you since you are already reviewing this PR

`wskadmin user list shared -p 2`

and for reference:

```
> wskadmin user list -h
usage: wskadmin user list [-h] [-p N] [-k] namespace

positional arguments:
  namespace       the namespace to lookup

optional arguments:
  -h, --help      show this help message and exit
  -p N, --pick N  show no more than N identities
  -k, --key       show only the keys
```

the default is 1 for `pick`.

great i got the point now ! Another doubt which is have is when one executes the command wsk namespace list <namespace name> , does it list the current user which is being set in property for the namespace ?
Because in wsk.props file, it correctly mentions the namespace but in command wsk namespace list <name> , it gives the name of user under tht namespace.

We shouldn't send the body as the meta object always. Since for form data, and json it's already the args this would effectively cut the allowed payload size in half. Further sending anything other than formdata or json object in the body will fail to match in the routes and will be rejected. 

So what is the goal here? To accept body other than formdata and json object? If so, 1. You will need a test for that, and 2. You'll need to also consider how to deal with the entity extractors which don't currently permit anything other  that afformenrioned types.

@romankhar you are including the same file changes across multiple PRs.
Please either have a PR have only the changes corresponding file changes to the PR, Or just one single PR with all change files.

#1897 
#1896 
#1895 
#1894
#1893 

PR are suppose to be independent change sets compared to what's in master.

If you wan to work with multiple PRs one per file, then only include one file per PR.
The way to do this is to
```
git checkout master
git checkout -b new_file1
modify docs/file1.md
#only git add this file1 and nothing else
git add docs/file1.md
git commit -m "changes for file1"
git push origin new_file1
#go to github to submit PR
```
Do the same for the file2.md
go back and do `git checkout master` and then create a new branch for file2
 take into account that when you do `git status` you will see file1 being untracked or modifed, don't worry just ignore it and just add file2 for PR2 `git add docs/file2.md`

A user (more appropriately a subject) is an account (associated with an identity). A namespace is logical structure for organizing assets. A subject may have more than one namespace.

A namespace may be shared, so when a subject lists assets in a namespace, they see all the assets stored there. (Think of namespace as a directory with group permissions - anyone in the group can list its contents.)

`wsk namespace list` currently lists ALL namespaces that a subject has rights to (think of this as the equivalent of `groups <userid>` in UNIX. This command I should add may be going away soon though - to be replaced with tooling specific to a identity management service instead.
the changes are good but i suggest adding a test for each of options and head specifically (ie mock a response for each of these and confirm the response is as expected).

I'll accept/merge this patch but this change highlights how the sequence implementation should be done with a state machine/akka actor. This will have the added benefit of reducing the state held in flight to just the "last" activation result.

@rabbah, I noticed the content restriction as I was manually testing. @csantanapr, @mdeuser, see above comments.
I believe the goal is to accept payloads other than JSON or Form Data. Users would be responsible for processing input in other forms themselves to make Whisk more flexible in the future.

I'm curious if there is a motivating use case or requirement underlying this change --- or is this done just to be general? Form data, json object, and query parameters should cover a large set of use cases.
